<answer from>



Mezcal
Member since: 25 May 2006
Total points: 656 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Firstly I think it is critical to work more closely with local communities and schools in the area near to the club. The focus should be homegrown, local, talent.



Then it is critical to try to make the 'working week' similar to that at top flight football - Let players feel the intensity and competition of regular youth league football. With actual recognition for the leading teams and players -By youth I define 16 onwards.



Prior to this and it would be expensive but a fruitful breeding ground for talent would be a football university/school, sponsored and paid for by the football clubs in partnership with corporate sponsors where the clubs, through scouting, and work with local schools and communities, find players they wish to nominate to the school, BUT crucially it is not 'their' player. Players then get unique football training from top flight coaches from the clubs (on rotation) and the FA. This would be combined with a proper education, perhaps vocational courses in case the football does not work out for them or is ended by injury.



At the end of the schooling period, 16 years of age, those leaving are put in to a draft type system where they are allocated a football club to work with on a random basis, and which they must stay with for at least 1 year, before being able to be traded out, unless on loan.



In this way the clubs all centralise the coaching and development of raw talent, are guaranteed to get a young player who has been trained to excellent levels, and who has played youth competitive football but also gives the smaller clubs the opportunity of landing a top talent for free. No transfer fees but instead a regular commitment from the clubs to fund the school to pay for it all, along with normal government funding as it would be a normal school.



Talented youth get top class football and normal education, clubs can let the development of talent be done by someone else, and a level playing field to ensure all clubs get to benefit rather than all the talent dissapearing in to one of the big clubs ( and better for the youth player to be at a club where they might get first team action sooner)
It also means the players get a focus on education and not just on football. Rather than having to choose between their studies and football they can have both, and if footie does not work out they have some qualification, academic or vocational to start adult life with.



It will work. And the cost to the clubs is offset by not having to invest quite so much on youth develpoment themselves. Corporates would love the once a year lottery for the top rated stars. And if the big clubs want to buy someone after a year, they can and the small clubs benefit. Genius!



</answer>

<answer from>



debswill...
Member since: 14 February 2007
Total points: 1880 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



On the whole, and under the circumstances, I think the youth system is probably as good as it could be. The Academy system is great, your local little boys and girls are picked out as being above average and invited into the Academy. They are pretty oblivious to the privilege and perform as normal. The problems can begin when they get older. They can become self conscious and loose confidence (due to the awkward age) and, due to the low proportion of successful English players at top level, probably lack some motivation. There are not many local role models around at the moment. Maybe if Academies could produce more 'local stars', it would have an impact and encourage others.



Source(s):



Personal experience.



</answer>

<answer>



Personally the FA could team up with the Government to offer a lot more school based football competitions with lot's of local scouts coming to see the finals/semi's in order to spot the best player's on the best teams. This would be easy as it would only be one game to watch for scouts on different dates.



Another idea is that higher local clubs should be able to make contracts with lower local clubs which allow recommendations of the youth for lower clubs to go on a trail at higher clubs (Something like 5 per Season). If they like the player at the trial, then the higher local will pay a fixed price for up and coming talent from that club (e.g. so no matter how good they are, it wil always be like £1,000 or something like that. Then better, unscouted youth will have a chance to get higher up in the ladder and the lower down clubs will have more money to invest in youth.



</answer>

<answer>



As a FA certified coach, Charter Standard League Training Officer and age group coordinator my suggestion would be to invest in the local independent clubs, they have a far greater view of local talent and tend to have more time for all players. who knows the next big player may be slightly struggling with the game at present and may not be picked up straight away by an academy. with clubs helping independent clubs then only the game can benefit

<answer from>



Author/L...
Member since: 13 February 2008
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think more noticeable improvements can be seen in the performance of young players if the clubs place greater emphasis on the mental side of the game.  This way the players will develop a greater sense of determination, resilience and foresight.  One of the reasons for this is that they will learn how to play the game in their head, through visualisation and other self-help techniques.  These are powerful strategies that some of the world’s greatest sportsmen and women have used to propel themselves to the very top of their sport.



I am at the completion stage of putting together a series of personal and professional development books aimed specifically at 14-19 year old aspiring footballers. I have teamed up one of the most experienced ex-professional footballers in Europe to put this series together. This ex-player is now an academy manager.



I feel this project will encourage these players to look at the game and their involvement with it from various angles.  It can only help to better prepare them to bring some of the most impressive talents to game, and at the same time get the most out of it.



</answer>



<answer from>



juniorsa...
Member since: 05 November 2007
Total points: 109 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



By understanding the philosophy and psychology of the top countries systems such as Spain, France and Brazil (too name a few). The FA should undertake this task and build this into their coach educators program, also providing workshops for existing coaches so everyone is on the same page. Development issues can easily be tracked this way. The winning mentality at young age has to stop and technique and creativity should be rewarded (meaning that clubs should advocate a development process not a team standing process). Junior Sargeant BSc Coaching Science/Sports psychology



</answer>

<original file>13793.html</original file>

<category>



Sports



Football (Soccer)



</category>



<question from>



NicK--&gt; exam time :(
Member since: 01 February 2008
Total points: 4398 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



English Football (Soccer)



</question from>



<question>



So does EVERYONE hate Liverpool now?



..when it was clearly a tit ref and NOT cheating Liverpool?



</question>



<additional details>



The only funny banter on here that isnt football related is Mrs Giggs and now Mrs Uranob. I am honoured to have your presence :P



You are all going on about an idiotic dive, funny cause Gerrard got his head to the ball before flying into the defender.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Anfield Abroad
Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 374 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



There are lots of clean challenges that take a player down.  Why is it always considered a dive when a player falls down?  Maybe Gerrard was fouled, maybe not, but regardless there was little chance that any player would land on his feet after that challenge.  The game is just too fast for 1 referee and two line judges.  I don't think replay is the answer, but what about two box judges on the by-lines?



On behalf of the refs, they know that they can book players for diving.  If Gerrard dived, then the ref should have waved the yellow card.  He didn't, so now everyone is suggesting that Gerrard and the ref are cheating.  Sounds like sour grapes.  The only questionable part of the call was whether or not it was a foul.  I for one think that it would have been a free kick anywhere else on the pitch, so why not a penalty in the box?  But both players were in the air and both went down.  If both went down, then how is the one who was fouled accused of diving?  Jump ball headers are always considered fouls when one player gets to the ball first and the other player hits him and not the ball.  It just rarely happens in the box.  Case Closed.



I agree with Sir Angelo on the point he made about Ronaldo.  Ronaldo was brought down by a clean challenge from a Bolton player.  The player made contact with the ball BEFORE the player, which is clean.  But it inevitably brought down the player too, and the ref wrongfully awarded a penalty.  But just because Ronaldo went down doesn't mean he dived.  And I'm a Liverpool supporter.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Excellent. I hope people read your answer and understand instead of just looking for the first person to blame.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



The boy from London
Member since: 13 October 2006
Total points: 9110 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most non-LFC fans probably do.



That said, the ref was an absolute joke.  Two decisions that clearly should have been corners to Liverpool were given as  goal kicks (in Athletico's favour) and then one decision that should have been a goal kick to Athletico was given as a corner.  Then there was the handball by the Athletico player which should have been given as penalty but the one that was NOT a penalty was given as a penalty.



Basically the officials were real clowns today.



</answer>



<answer from>



LFC [Fer9Tor] GiRl
Member since: 11 October 2008
Total points: 123 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



no way I hate Liverpool... I'm a true Liverpool fan and have sided with them for ages and don't even imagine siding with anyone else.

Liverpool can lose every game there is there to play...I will still be supporting them cause every time I see them play I fall in love with football all over again!



And those people who side with a different team every season are complete and total morons cause football isn't about winning its about coming together as a team and win or lose together!



Liverpool the best! -support and believe!



</answer>

Has anyone read Steven Gerrard's new book?



Here's some of the testimonials.



"Steve Gerrard's new book, The Cenotes of the Riviera Maya is a must buy for any diver. I keep a copy in the van I use for diving just to show my diving buddies and other divers that I meet, and I have yet to meet a diver who is not instantly taken by it." – Donn Ellerbrock



"Steve Gerrard shows off his consummate skills as a cave diver in a useful and entertaining format. This book is necessary for cave divers and will be treasured by anyone interested in discovering the most beautiful and mysterious place on earth." – Bradley A. Caudle



"Steve Gerrard has created a masterpiece with this book. His knowledge...(is) a blessing to the diving community!" – Angus and Joy Barnhart



Ironically, Steve Gerrard has a namesake in England who also wrote a book about diving.



Here are some of the extracts:



SG: "Players like Carvalho and Ronaldo are damaging football."



SG: "If I saw a team-mate doing it, I would definitely have a word."



SG: "I don't think there's anything worse than a player diving when no one's been anywhere near him. It does ruin the game."

<question>



Has anyone read Steven Gerrard's new book?



Here's some of the testimonials.



"Steve Gerrard's new book, The Cenotes of the Riviera Maya is a must buy for any diver. I keep a copy in the van I use for diving just to show my diving buddies and other divers that I meet, and I have yet to meet a diver who is not instantly taken by it." – Donn Ellerbrock



"Steve Gerrard shows off his consummate skills as a cave diver in a useful and entertaining format. This book is necessary for cave divers and will be treasured by anyone interested in discovering the most beautiful and mysterious place on earth." – Bradley A. Caudle



"Steve Gerrard has created a masterpiece with this book. His knowledge...(is) a blessing to the diving community!" – Angus and Joy Barnhart



Ironically, Steve Gerrard has a namesake in England who also wrote a book about diving.



Here are some of the extracts:



SG: "Players like Carvalho and Ronaldo are damaging football."



SG: "If I saw a team-mate doing it, I would definitely have a word."



SG: "I don't think there's anything worse than a player diving when no one's been anywhere near him. It does ruin the game."



LOOK:
http://www.cenotesoftherivieramaya.com/t...



</question>



<additional details>



http://www.goal.com/en-india/Articolo.as...



http://www.manchesterunited.vitalfootbal...

"STEVIE: I'M NO FALL GUY
Gerrard gets all confused in The Daily Express, saying: "In my mind it was a penalty," before adding that "if it had happened at the other end, we would have been livid". "

Cristiano Ronaldo's exaggerated tumble was the feature of Manchester United's win over Middlesbrough in Dec 2006. Gareth Southgate described the winger as a serial diver, but when Sky's Geoff Shreeves approached Ferguson for his reaction the response was rather different:



Shreeves: Listen, are you going to do the interview in a professional manner or not? Do you want to do it or not?



Ferguson: You f------ be professional. You be professional. You're the one.



Shreeves: I'm entitled to ask... Cristiano gave the right answer.



Ferguson: F------ hell with your answers.



Shreeves: Don't talk to me like that. Go away. If you want to behave civilly, fine. Don't talk to me like that.

Sports

<question from>



Foxhound
Member since: 05 January 2007
Total points: 516 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Should the Stoke City style long throw-in be banned?



It may not be against the letter of the law but it is certainly against the spirit of the beautiful game. Football should be about keeping the ball on the ground as much as possible, creating opportunities through passing and moving. That is why it is called FOOTball! The ugly long thrown-in is all about brawn and no brains. The throw-in is itself an anomaly in football anyway and only derives from its roots in Rugby. It is the only time an outfield player is allowed to touch the ball with his hands and as such, it is about time it was removed. A few years ago FIFA were considering changing the law to allow the ball to be kicked back into play along the ground from the sideline when the ball went out. I think they should have enforced that change. Stoke exemplify everything that is ugly about the game - hoof the ball upfield to the big guy and muscle it into the net, fouling as many of the opposition as possible along the way. They should have shown more respect to Arsenal last week (and the other top teams when they play them) and watched and learnt how the game should be played. I feel the time to ban the thrown-in and, especially the long throw-in that the Stoke City Neanderthal specialises in, has come. It has no place in the modern game. I will be writing to FIFA about this as well. Opinions please!



</question>



<answer from>



spurs_ha...
Member since: 06 April 2008
Total points: 4382 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>

<question from>



Laser II..
Member since: 23 August 2008
Total points: 279 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



I need help to get back into the game?



Well i sprained my ankle pretty bad the 20th last month and was out for a Month and a week now that im back I suck really bad



I Play goalkeeper and defender and i have to say i was really good before i sprained it now that im back i lost my diving skills,i get really nervous at a ball rolling at the ground and i let in a goal rolling in the ground today at a scrimmage.



When i was defender half time i did so bad i was lost i was just following the guy like i dint know where the ball was and i was taking so long to pass the ball eventually they took the ball away from me so many times they almost scored before my injury i was so good at both GOALKEEPER AND DEFENDER now i suck what can i do to get it back i have an important game this weekend



thanks..



</question>



<answer from>



obanpuss...
Member since: 13 June 2007
Total points: 11548 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



1) learn the basic terminology
2) become very skillful very quickly
3) obtain  a professional contract at a top premier league club (as you're good at diving you should be a shoe in at sold trafford)-this will allow you to ''earn'' an obscene amount of money in a very short time



hope this helps



</answer>



<answer from>



el nino
Member since: 10 December 2007
Total points: 2998 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Fitness and quick thinking is what you need.Fitness doesn't happen over night but quick thinking can,so instead of trying to run the ball,try and look for the easy way out and pass it quicker than the player against you.
Start a fitness test and take a long look ans see where you are lacking.It takes time to get back to full fitness,so don't worry just get started and try to be a bit quicker passing the ball and your confidence will return in time



</answer>

<question from>



youbythg
Member since: 06 November 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Which soccer country won most World Cups?



I think it is Brazil...Is it?



</question>



<answer from>



Pai Kia
Member since: 18 April 2007
Total points: 11701 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Movies



English Football (Soccer)



</answer from>



<answer>



brazil, 5 times champions



Brazil won their first Cup in 1958 (Sweden), their second in Chile ('62), their third in Mexico ('70). They waited 24 long years before picking up their fourth trophy in 1994 (U.S.), and their fifth came in Japan in '02.



</answer>



<answer from>



tony da red devil
Member since: 22 April 2008
Total points: 2304 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



brazil.................5



italy..................4



</answer>



<answer from>



LiNzi - Engaged!!
Member since: 20 June 2008
Total points: 10193 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Brazil - 5 times



</answer>



<answer from>



el nino
Member since: 10 December 2007
Total points: 3006 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The FIFA World Cup Trophy, which has been awarded to the world champions since 1974.



Founded 1930



Region International (FIFA)



Number of teams 204 (Qualifiers for 2010)
32 (Finals)



Current champions  Italy (4th title)



Most successful team  Brazil (5 titles)



</answer>

<question from>

<question>

<answer>



Honestly, at game speed I thought it could go either way.  The ref missed 3 handballs total (2 by Atletico and 1 by Liverpool) and didn't call any.  Also, Agger was brought down in the box 2 minutes into the match.  Initially I thought the ref was just scared of calling a penalty that early in the game, but in retrospect, I think he just cowered from calling penalties at all.  Liverpool deserved a goal and were justly rewarded.



Supporters of other teams, be honest, YOU WOULD ALL HAVE CALLED THAT PENALTY A GOOD CALL IF IT WENT FOR YOUR TEAM!!



@Pai Kia



If the ref didn't want Liverpool to lose, why would he wait until the very last minute of stoppage time to call a penalty when he  had plenty of chances to call for [apparently] less controversial spot kicks?  He couldn't be sure that he would even have the opportunity to call a penalty at that point.  Refs don't throw the games, and saying otherwise is sour grapes.



</answer>

</question>

i did say, WHILE YOU RECKON

<question>



Which shop would your club be?



Manchester United : - Sainsbury Superstore: Best option for Out of Towners



Chelsea :- Tesco: Making a desperate bid for world domination and hated for it



Liverpool:- Army & Navy Store: Two opposing forces permanently at war



Manchester City:- Harrods: Expensive , Fancy pretentions but a template to bad taste



Arsenal:- Calais Hypermarket: Cheap Duty free imports bundled through dover



West Ham:- Iceland: Kerry Kotona diet for a Jeremy Kyle crowd



Fulham:- Liberty: Quaint and Traditional but whiffs of old people



Hull:- Lidl : Cheap , no frills , delivers surprising value for money



Newcastle Utd:- Next : Next manager , Next Owner , Next Crisis



Aston Villa:- Morrisons : Never quite appealing as the advert promises



Portsmouth:- TK Maxx : Jumble shop full of old designer name castoffs



Tottenham : -Marks & Sparks : Looks good on the shelf but hideously overpriced



Everton :- Thomas Cook Travel : Threatening to go under in the credit crunch any day



LA Galaxy:- Victoria Wines : only explination for David Beckham going there



many thanks to whichever paper published this



</question>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



So I came home tonight and my wife was standing at the end of the close with a thermometer in her mouth?



When I asked her why, she said the Doctor told her to take her temperature in the back passage.



</question>



<answer from>



bear in the big blue house
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 495 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Arthur Davidson, of the Harley Davidson Motorcycle Corporation, died and went to heaven. At the gates, St. Peter told Arthur, "Since you've been such a good man and your motorcycles have changed the world, your reward is, you can hang out with anyone you want in Heaven."



Arthur thought about it for a minute, and said "I want to hang out with God."



St. Peter took Arthur to the Throne Room, and introduced him to God. Arthur then asked God, "Hey, aren't you the inventor of woman?" God said, "Ah, yes."



"Well," said Arthur, "You have some major design flaws in your invention.



1. There's too much inconsistency in the front end protrusion.
2. It chatters constantly at high speeds.



3. Most of the rear ends are too soft and wobble too much.
4. The intake is placed way to close to the exhaust.



5. The maintenance costs are outrageous."



"Hmmmm, you may have some good points there," replied God, "hold on."
God went to his Celestial Supercomputer, typed in a few words, and waited for the results. The computer printed out a slip of paper and God read it.
"Well, it may be true that my invention is flawed," God said to Arthur,



"but according to these numbers, more people are riding my invention than yours."



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Which of these clubs is more popular in England: Man Utd, Liverpool, Arsenal or Chelsea?

The Option™ (London Edition): Did you know that.....?



It has been 53 since Tottenham made such a bad start to a league season.
Q1 - Does this mean that Spurs fans can hope for a good start for Tottenham next year?



It took 50 years for Chel$ki to win the domestic league.



Q2 - Does this mean that Chel$ki fans can wait for another 50 years for them to win their 4th title?



75 percent of the goals conceded by Arsenal in the Premier League this season have been scored directly from corners.
Q3 - Do the Gunners really play better with its first choice back four 5'11" height average?



</question>

<original file>index;_ylt=AgMIIY3Y7OQaXvuUEyyO1.7TBwxafff.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk33985.txt</current file name>



<category>



Sports



Football (Soccer)



</category>



<question from>



wantanan...
Member since: 04 June 2008
Total points: 117 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is american football exactly and how is it different from soccer or football?



</question>



<answer from>



not.me
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 147 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Well first of all soccer is called "football" almost everywhere in the world except for the US.. in which soccer is called well soccer.. and football is the well-known NFL. The rest of the world calls this sport "american football". Now soccer (football), is played mostly with player's feet, actually a hand contact with the ball in-play is penalized, only the goalkeeper is allowed to do this and only in certain parts of the field. On the contrary football (american football) is played mostly throwing the ball with player's hands, of course both have exceptions like a field goal (kicked) in football and



a side throw (handed) in soccer. Also in soccer a goal equals a +1 score, in football a field goal equals +3, a touchdown equals +6 plus a +1 or +2 depending on the play immediately performed after a touchdown.



Hope this gives you a clear perspective on the main differences.



Source(s):



i play both sports



</answer>



<asker's comment>



i understood the thing....thanks a lot.



</asker's comment>

<question>



Ball hitting referee?



in football if someone kicks the ball at the referee and goes in the goal does it count as a goal?



</question>



<answer from>



Doctor Der
Member since: 14 January 2008
Total points: 467 (Level 2)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



yes because the referee is a part of the field. Basically he's the same as grass except they've got a whistle and are in charge of the game,



</answer>

</asker's comment>

<question>



How can I now see EPL football in Indonesia as Astro TV don't have the rights?



This seems to be an annual problem here, with rival companies cutting each other's thoats for the rights, but this time it seems no-one has them. Astro didn't even have the decency to warn customers. Internet connections are slow and unreliable here too, so streamed games don't seem to be a viable option. If anyone can tell me any provider still operating here or a way to get satellite pictures from abroad, I will build a cathedral in your name (or maybe just be eternally grateful!) It is outrageous that the 4th most populous nation in the world can't watch the largest and best sport in the world. Thank you very, very much in advance for any help.



</question>

<question>



Should player communication with the referee during a game be limited to only the team captain? If so, why?



</question>



<answer from>



Rowan
Member since: 23 March 2006
Total points: 11732 (Level 6)



</answer from>

</answer>

<answer>



Yes, it should be.

All the players are frustrated at that point and can scream and swear at the referees.

The captain is chosen because he is calm in most situations and he has great communication skills. If he alone goes and talks to the referee he will be able to get the point across more easily and clearly, rather than all the players screaming.



</answer>

<answer>



Yes.

It helps prevent intimidation of the referee and makes the game a more civil occasion.  I have children, I do not want to see them watching loads of players swearing at a referee.

It also would prevent a disgraceful recurrence of the events when Gustavo Dezotti's red card was shown in the 1990 world cup final.  No referee should ever be treated like that, worse that it was in the world cup final.

<answer from>



Bob P
Member since: 06 December 2006
Total points: 7606 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



In a perfect game, there should be no reason for communication to the referee by players. However we do not live in a perfect world.

There are requirements for clarification of referees' wishes and decisions. These should be adequately handled by the Team Captain. Rugby grasped this one by the horns many years ago and it works.

In Rugby backchat sees a penalty advanced by 10 metres, scrums changed to penalties and penalties reversed. In extremis it sees a player dispatched to the "sin bin". You NEVER see the ref getting harrassed!

The only surprise in Football is that the rule has not been brought in!

Nor do we yet see the sin bin, which would be a much more appropriate punishment than the current Yellow Card. A prompt punishment, commensurate with the offence, gives the offender time to reflect and cool down, while removing the fear of accumulated demerits, leading to bans.



</answer>



<answer from>



203
Member since: 02 March 2007
Total points: 8932 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is desperately needed in football.

It works perfectly well in rugby and of course the captain must also refer to the referee as "sir". If other players have something to raise with the referee they do so via their captain. A perfectly sensible chain of command.

It would return some respect and order to the game. The way some players behave like thugs and yobs rushing into and getting in the face of the referee is a disgrace to football.



</answer>

Blazing Pen Avenger.

<answer from>



roger.wi...
Member since: 03 November 2006
Total points: 10446 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is immoral how much many footballers are paid. Wages in excess of £100,000 per week are ridiculous at any time but especially so during a period of financial strife.However, the laws of supply and demand allow for this to happen for you only have to compare footballers such as Ronaldo, Rooney. Terry etc with film stars and you can appreciate why it happens. Of course some people in our society deserve higher wages than footballers but we have allowed it to happen by supporting teams by paying huge entrance fees and watching them on TV. If gates fall appreciably and people stop watching football on TV then  possibly things may change.



</answer>

<question from>



AXBT

</question from>



<question>



Need help with football boots?



I am looking to buy a pair of football boots but need help.
I play as an attacking midfielder and striker.
What boots should i buy?
price isnt an option..
i dont do trickery but do shoot and need control with power and speed!!



</question>



<additional details>



i do a hell of alot runnimg in a match!!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Ray R
Member since: 22 February 2008
Total points: 545 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need the adidas Predator PowerSwerve TRX Firm Ground Football Boots.

Worn by attacking midfielders such Gerrard, Anderson and Ballack.

Have a look at the link.



Source(s):



http://www.prodirectsoccer.com/prodinfo....



</answer>



<answer from>



mrpandam...
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 540 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You want to get good boots, but they're not everything, so they won't help with your skills, but total 90 shoot are really good and they're relatively cheap, but if price isn't a problem I'd go with the total 90 laser's because they're the same series but just better, but they are more expensive!



</answer>



<answer from>



celtic
Member since: 17 March 2007
Total points: 345 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Some good boots are the adidas predator series, the total 90's and the mercurial vapors. The most important thing is comfort and that really is determined by the shape of your foot compared to the boot. Try lots of boots on and pick the most comfortable one. If you buy kangaroo leather (used by most boots over $150) by half a size small or really snug. It will expand to fit the shape of your foot. Always go for real leather shoes, they are more durable and have better ball feel. Control, Power, speed, shooting is really up the the player. All that technology doesn't really help you that much, though it is to run in lighter shoes. If you don't mind being traditional, the air legends and adipures are great boots.



</answer>






<original file>index;_ylt=AlQYSbLH7VV_qnbVQsRzQvbTBwx5458.html</original file>

<question from>



Owen - R9

<question>



Is £30 million Cheap in Football now?



Many players in recent years have been touted as potential transfers exceeding $£30 such as Adebeyour, Shevchenko, Henry etc. During the mid-late 90's youd never hear of much exceeding 20 million (except in the case of Ronaldo or Vieri) which is todays equivalent of 50 mil. So is 30mil a bit run of the mil now?



</question>



<answer from>



js
Member since: 22 August 2006
Total points: 763 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I Can remember when the first Million £ player was sold Trevor Francis Birmingham to forest. The prices are just going to get higher and higher! Only the high profile players are going to be bought for £30 + milliion and there only a few clubs who can afford those price madrid,chelsea man u,inter ETC



</answer>



<answer from>



aidod15
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



No it it is definitely not cheap.Not many clubs can afford that type of price tag and those that can wont give it up easily.There has been a downturn in prices in the last couple of years and most clubs are watching their purse strings.It seems to be on the rise again but new owners especially in the english clubs will baulk at spending that type of money.There will be exceptions of course for exceptional players but £30 million is a lot of cash and if i was running a club i would have to look long and hard before spending that kind of money.



</answer>



<answer from>



Invasion
Member since: 08 December 2006
Total points: 2511 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Now a days Clubs want to know to what other club they are selling to... Once they know how potential you are then they will try to get rich through your budget.

There is no way any of the named players can be sold over that price if the the club requesting their service is Birmingham or Sunderland.



</answer>

<answer from>



James K

<answer>



Hmmm , well im not sure how to convert your money exchange but I do know some cleats that fit your description. Well first of all do you have a wide foot? If you do you will be looking for DIadora or Joma. But if you dont and your foot can fit into nike/adidas and anyother shoe then I would recommend : T 90 Laser II, for accuracy they opened up expensive but I would believe they might be a little cheaper now. Mesh (to breathe), expandable, and a increased sweet spot. The Adidas Predator is built for speed and ball control. WIth comfort. The ultimate power boot around is the Adidas Predator PS TRX FG. You can go online for all of this, because Adidas has a good boot period. They design specific ones for specific things so listing them all would be pointless. But i would go with some kind of Adidas predator.  And let me just inform you that (this is factual) NIKE leather is the best. You may of known this already but the nike leather is better then kangaroo. It doesnt hold water (so you dont get weighed down), and it is supposed to give you a better touch. The top  nike boot would be the Nike Air Legend II (2), again I dont knwo your price range. This boot has a good control, and a powerfull shot. If your looking for comfort try the Tiempo Mystic from Nike. I also have to agree that any boot from nike that is comfortable for you will probably work out. Well thats all I have for now. I have a Diadora pair right now and I am more then satisfied, mainly because i have a very wide foot. But remember its not about the boot its about the player wearing them.



</answer>

<answer from>



Michael P
Member since: 21 January 2007
Total points: 11975 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



There's a lot of great athletes whose names mean the wrong thing in the country in which they play.  A lot of Japanese players have names like Yamashita (Yah-mah-SHEE-tah) or Fukudome (Foo-koo-DOH-may) that don't work well in U.S. baseball.  Then there's the Slovak hockey player Miroslav Satan (Sha-TAN), who, ironically, not only hasn't played for the New Jersey Devils but usually plays very well against them.  (To my dismay: I'm a Devils fan.) Then there's Bob Owchinko, who pitched for the San Diego Padres, then washed out, and signed with a team in Japan, unaware that "Owchinko" sounded like their word for, how shall I put this... insufficient equipment.

But Ricardo Izecson dos Santos Leite, alias Kaka (Kuh-KAH), a man of deep faith, should thank God he plays in Brazil (national team) and Italy (AC Milan), and not in the U.S. where commentators can make snide remarks about his name sounding like a slang term for crap.  Which is too bad, because he's a fantastic player.



</answer>



<answer from>



haobangx...
Member since: 13 June 2008
Total points: 2649 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Papin



</answer>

<category>



Sports



Football (Soccer)



</category>



<question from>



rangaz44
Member since: 19 January 2008
Total points: 132 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Help for college soccer... how can i gain exposure even though i dont play school ball?



I'm going into my senior year of high school and im really interested in playing or at least trying to play in college. The only issue is i dont play for my school team because of the politics involved.  To get an idea of my skill level i played 2 years of freshmen in 8th and 9th grade (starter the second) and 1 year of jv in 10th grade (also started) before i became fed up with the unfair treatment by the coaches.



Right now i am playing for a local club team and wil lbe playing in a u21 winter league with college players.  I was wondering if there are any other things i can do to gain some exposure to college scouts or coaches even though i'm not playing for a school team which puts me at a disadvantage.
any suggestions would be greatly appreciated



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Well with all due respect it's pretty obvious you're not going to get a full scholarship to a division I program or anything like that. Find out if there is any Division III/NAIA college programs in or near your area, visit their website, contact their coach, send him your resume, and try to get him to come out and watch you play. Also, try going to college soccer camps to gain exposure. Best of luck mate



</answer>

<question from>

Member since: 13 August 2006

</question from>



<question>



How do I get more power in my shots when playing football ?



I have got lost of power in my shots but I want more so how do I get lots of power in my shots so they are not saveable ?



</question>



<answer from>



tongue in cheek
Member since: 18 September 2007
Total points: 2951 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Go to Moss Side and buy a more powerful gun.



</answer>



<answer from>



jaydanma...
Member since: 29 June 2007
Total points: 196 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



owwwwwwwwwh!
another manutd supporter glory glory manutd
i have the same problem



</answer>



<answer from>



I Rock
Member since: 15 July 2008
Total points: 231 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Follow Through as if you are trying to knee yourself in the head.



</answer>



<answer from>



James
Member since: 09 March 2007
Total points: 178 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would have thought building up your leg muscle strength would have been the best idea, do some squats, squat thrusts etc, build up your hamstrings, quad-draceps.  Practice kicking your football, I used to just belt it as hard as I could against a wall, loads of times, until i was nackered.
Just train and discipline, thats what you need!!



</answer>



<answer from>



I wanna dance like Tevez.
Member since: 04 May 2008
Total points: 813 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



a lot of footballers throw their body into the shot,acting like its the last one they'll ever make.take a deep breath in and breathe out heavily when striking the ball,this kinda works phsychologically and physically,and it's also helpful in cricket when bowling.other than that,just practice a lot..you will gain more skill and find it becomes slightly easier to put more force into the ball,some people even find it becomes their bodies natural instinct to kinda kick the ball really hard...but you know,whichever method works for you.



</answer>



<answer from>



Andy L
Member since: 29 September 2007
Total points: 3369 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



kick the ball harder.



</answer>



<answer from>



El Rey Gato -&gt;Spain Campeones
Member since: 28 June 2007
Total points: 12900 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Strong muscles are one answer
My power came when I learned to lock my ankle down and kick through the ball at the laces and meet the median of the ball (instep drive).  Accuracy went to heck, but if its power you want, that's the ticket.



</answer>



<answer from>



Michael w
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 111 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i have  developed a pretty hard shot that also dips/knuckles/has lots of movement. my trick is that i "snap' my knee as i am going to kick the ball. go to kick the ball as you usually would but instead of kicking it normally you should strike the ball with your laces and accelerate your foot through the ball. it is tought to explain exactly how i do it but i hope you are able to understand what i am trying to say. when i kick the ball i usually get quite a bit of pace on the ball along with some movement. this really throws keepers off. also when shooting it is not always about kicking the hardest. you have to remember to place the ball where the keeper cannot save it. when you try to kick the ball as hard as you can you lose much of your ability to aim where you kick it



</answer>



<answer from>



Dan D
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 138 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



just use ur toes. ur a manc i will hit some **** and go in.



</answer>



<answer from>



mikey
Member since: 03 July 2006
Total points: 3856 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



hit the ball with your foot square on and use as much follow through as possible....keep your knee over the ball and don't lean back. Your leg and foot are your equipment in the same way a golf club or tennis racket is... follow through is everything...even if it's not power you're going for just accuracy. How well does a golf club, tennis racket, snooker cue etc etc work without follow through????



Could try developing your leg muscles as well of course.



</answer>



<answer from>



GIGGS is OO7©
Member since: 14 May 2008
Total points: 1677 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



if you know the basic technique then practise is the only thing left, planting your standing foot correctly and getting your kicking legs, knee over the ball is for basic raw power, obviously using the laces as your sweet spot, the only problem is you have very little control over the direction.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mr 2Points
Member since: 12 July 2008
Total points: 289 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Lol sometimes people fail to under stand it's not always about the power
how about your accuracy, composer?



</answer>

<question>



Do you think if there was a Great Britain football team in the Olympics?



that this would allow for greater home based talent to nurture within our nations and then give better players for the seperate teams in the future?



</question>



<answer from>



The Ghost
Member since: 27 April 2006
Total points: 10930 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Vilcho from Argentina ♥
Member since: 30 October 2007
Total points: 7698 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Languages



</answer from>



<answer>



No way.(Anyway, Argentina would beat  Great Britain being together or in separate countries)



</answer>



<answer from>



Dave of Stoft
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 265 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The Olympics happen once every 4 years whereas the European and World Championships alternate every 2 years... The Olympics themselves have very little impact in the football world in comparison to the other competitions.

The reason why there is a lack of British footballing talent is mainly due to cost. A top team can buy several top quality players from abroad for 8 to 9 million pounds but a home grown player tends to demand much more.



Consider the case of Darren Bent, an OK English player but bought for the same price as Thierry Henry... I know who i'd prefer in my squad.

Once English players become less greedy you'll see a change in the attitude of the premiership



</answer>

<question from>



ulsterbo...

</question from>



<question>



Who will have the most solid defense next year?



in  the english premiership



</question>



<additional details>



AND WHY?......................



AND WHY?......................



</additional details>



<answer from>



jackusse...
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 114 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>

<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Dame LiNzi
Member since: 20 June 2008
Total points: 1552 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Arsenal!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Julian Smith
Member since: 28 April 2008
Total points: 156 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Out of the big four (Chelsea, Liverpool, Arsenal, Man U), I think there is no arguing Chelsea will be first.



John Terry, for starters. He's by far one of the best defenders in the world, let alone the premier league. You also have newcomer Jose Bosingwa from FC Porto, a great defender who can attack on the flanks as well. Ricardo Carvalho and Ashley Cole are also very solid defenders. While Petr Cech had a poor Euro, he is still one of the best keepers.

Next comes Man U, Nemanja Vidic and Rio are one of the best duo's in defending in the premier league. Wings include the vicious attacker Evra and either Gary Neville, Wes Brown, and occasionally Owen Hargreaves (this is their weak point). Van der Saar performed admirably at the Euros as well as in the Champs League, and I think Kuszczak is going to be one of the best in a couple of years.

Coming in third in my view is Liverpool. While all are very experienced and solid at the back, they're getting old. I'm pretty sure Jamie Carragher has been around since football was invented and Sami Hyypia is slooooooowwww. I like youngster Martin Skrtel, but it'll take time before he makes a real impact. Agger, Arbeloa, Aurelio, and Finnan are also decent defenders. Pepe Reina is a great keeper, he provides a wall for the goal and can also use his accurate kicking skills to start a strong counter.

Arsenal unfortunately comes last... While I think they have a GREAT defense, I don't think they'll be able to work well together. Gallas and Toure are very very good, but OLD. Sagna, Clichy, and Eboue are also very good defending, but they don't know how to work with the rest of the defense and they tend to do a little too much attacking. I really like Almunia at GK, it took a lot of balls to steal the spotlight from Lehmann!



</answer>



<answer from>

<question from>



*FOOTY FANATIC*
Member since: 05 January 2008
Total points: 3753 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



What Exactly Is Simplicity?



...wen it comes to football what is simplicity and what is dificulty!



</question>



<additional details>



@ KRATOS
ermm wot r u on about?



</additional details>



<answer from>



The DOC
Member since: 25 June 2008
Total points: 2182 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Homework Help



Mathematics



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Simplicity : Doing the basics of football well, most commonly pass and move, organization etc.

Difficulty : needlessly complicating things by trying moves and passes that are not in the players repertoire

Winner is always simplicity and for me is the more attractive way of playing football



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

<question>



Question about Football Boots?



My mate said that the regular foot size you are (mine is 5) that you should get boots that are 1 upper size than you are now, so to make the question easier,



Shall I get Football boots (blades) in size 6 when I am in size 5?



</question>



<answer from>



Happy Man
Member since: 07 October 2007
Total points: 10529 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes it is because football socks are so thick.



</answer>



<answer from>



elliot pieper the soccer player
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 191 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



get the 6 size if u dont have soccer show allready got the  size 5 because u well grow into the size 6 and then u dont have to buy a pair



</answer>



<answer from>



KP
Member since: 03 May 2006
Total points: 4494 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



you need to try on the shoes. Make sure there is extra room for your toes. It explains why you get one size more than your actual size. But every brand name shoes designs different. You can't trust on size. Try on before you buy is the best way to buy the shoes you like.



</answer>



<answer from>



The Real Special One
Member since: 21 April 2007
Total points: 626 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



What every feels best for you. I wear wide fit boots but have narrow feet so my boots are always half a size smaller.
My friend wears a whole size smaller because he thinks that way you get a better feel for the ball that way. 
I have never known anyone to wear a size up though



</answer>



<answer from>



Kyle
Member since: 01 March 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Which ever one feels best

I'd recommend the larger pair just because the socks are so thick, though.



</answer>



<answer from>



celtic
Member since: 17 March 2007
Total points: 345 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have never heard of anyone getting cleats a size large except for maybe toddlers who will grow. cleats should fit quite snug so you have maximum control over your movement and to avoid blisters on your feet. Soccer socks are not thick enough to fill and entire size difference compared to normal socks and some brands (admiral in particular) have thinner than normal socks. Socker socks also tend to get thinner the more you use them and the extra space in front of the toe can mess with your shooting (on a full shot, you will not be able to hit the ball with the ideal part of the top of your foot without snagging the ground). Since leather, especially kangaroo leather has a tendency to expand after use, I would suggest buying shoes half a size or a size smaller than your normal size and let it expand to the shape of your foot. Some players like Cristiano Ronaldo wear 3 sizes smaller, but that is a bit extreme. A Snug fit is better than an oversize fit, so I would go with a size 4.5 or 5.



</answer>

<category>



Sports

<question from>



rakky000...
Member since: 11 May 2008
Total points: 136 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Beginner freestyle football tricks ?



Can someone give me the names of some freestyle football tricks that i can learn preferably some easy ones that a bigginer could learn



</question>



<answer from>



celtic
Member since: 17 March 2007
Total points: 345 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If you mean tricks while juggling, these are the ones I first learned.
1)back stall-practice by throwing the ball up and catching it one your back by pushing your shoulders back and bending down at the right time to absorb the bounce.
2)atw-practice by dropping the ball and putting your leg around the ball before hitting it the second time.
3)heel/butt stall-catching the ball between your heel and your butt. You have to get your leg into the right shape and squeeze softly when you get the ball
4)rabona juggle-put one leg over the ball while its dropping and hit it with the other foot that you must jump off of.
5)head stall-just takes practice balancing the ball on your hairline. Really good party trick.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



this realy helps, thankyou



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



John
Member since: 20 May 2008
Total points: 517 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i dont know any but you can type "freestyle tricks learn" at the search engines
or maybe somebody here know a good site
good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



wordxzaz
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 122 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



if you're looking for jukes,
try the bicycle, a simple fake to either side
even a simple change of speed can fool defenders
try searching videos

as far as juggling the ball goes.
you should first start off just getting used to the ball, juggle as much as possible everyday and practice. once you get a feel for it then the tricks will come naturally. like the around the world trick

if not try youtubing or googling and look at videos of experienced players breakdown the tricks it helps me a lot with my training.

hope this helped and good luck
:]



</answer>

<question from>



scott m

<question>



Work permits........



European footballers, do they need a work permit to sign for a English club.



</question>



<answer from>



Marty
Member since: 29 May 2008
Total points: 2209 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



If the European country is an EU member state, they do not require a permit to work.



Source(s):



I'm English and work all over mainland Europe. I do not require a work permit.



</answer>



<answer from>



mal
Member since: 18 October 2007
Total points: 11954 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



not if they were born in Europe.....



</answer>



<answer from>



Stuartk1...
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 113 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



no but any Non-EU player needs a permit but if you have played for their country he does not need one



</answer>

<question from>

<answer from>



Captain Starkiller
Member since: 10 April 2007
Total points: 21981 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Politics



</answer from>



<answer>



No.

The problem in the English league is the over inflated prices that you have to pay for home grown players.  Capping will not solve the problem.  You will still be able to buy a 'better' quality player for less from abroad.  That does not help English clubs, and does not help the development of English players (along with Welsh and Scots).

As for clubs abroad, they will find ways round a cap.  Look at how things were subverted when there was a wage cap in England.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salary_cap



</answer>

<answer>



Difficult to see how friend.

Other than by communism.  Market forces will always dictate these things, I'm sorry to say; or rather I'm not sorry to say.

Addenda:

Any father with a son going into football will want to see him earning has much as he can.  Wouldn't you now, with respect, take the best offer going?

However; like in all businesse's, contracts should be honoured, unless of illness, or shame being brought on a club:  Like Mutu did with Chelsea.  And I don't support them.

Contract's should be fair both ways.  If so, no one can stop the market; other than the market!

Football, won't go bust, despite prophecies to the opposite.  Local fan's often support their club, and a bigger one.  That's their perogative.



</answer>

<answer from>



Goodchil...
Member since: 22 May 2007
Total points: 225 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Can player transfer prices go up indefinitely?



The answer is most likely yes, money makes the world go round, none more so than in Football. It is just the way it is. However this money should be used in a better way. The huge transfer fees should be taxed by the governing bodies and the money should be put back into grass roots football of the country that the team is from. This way the bigger clubs give something back, and the national team will stand a chance in the future.



Should they be capped?

In a moral, ideal world, of course. But football is now a toy town.

If anything needs capping it is the price of tickets, especially as we move forward or the regular fan will simply not be able to watch his/her team.



Source(s):



The BBC is very often a great source for all.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 04 June 2008
Total points: 219 (Level 1)

<answer>



No.

Because quite simply clubs will just ask for the capped transfer amount and then proceed to ask for additional clauses.
So many payments of £ per players appearance or match wins. The clubs will find ways around it and still end up with the same amount of money they intended to have in the first place.
So really even if the transfer prices are capped, the value of the transfer wont be.

It's uncontrollable.



</answer>



<answer from>



Chigzy D
Member since: 15 June 2007
Total points: 1822 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hey Stefan …. In my words ‘The German Roy Keane’!!! (I find it difficult to understand when I read some say they have never heard of you….. obviously their knowledge of football does not go past last couple of years) …. I DON’T believe transfer prices should be capped.  This would give players even more power then already what exists in world football.

If a player wants it to be capped to a valuation then he should keep a CLAUSE while signing a contract which would allow them to leave for a transfer fee.  For example if C. Ronaldo has a CLAUSE when signing contract saying any club who bids £80 million for him the bid will be accepted then that’s fine he had it in the contract and hence he is allowed to talk with the club for a possible move.  BUT if there is NO CLAUSE then its his clubs right weather to accept any bid or not no matter how big it is.



</answer>

mattbids

</answer from>



<answer>



Great to have a genuine football player on here and one who won so many tittles.

In the free market that we live in I think it would be very hard to cap transfers at the moment. Michel Platini is implementing some pretty radical ideas as president of UEFA so I guess he could raise the idea.



I would like to see a player wage cap however or a draft system like they do in American sport where the teams who haven’t done so well the previous year get first pick on the up and coming players, so you don’t just get the big clubs winning everything year in year out.



</answer>

<question>



Will you raise your glass in memory?



To the people who perished in the 2 Ibrox disasters.....

The Ibrox Disaster

New Year Bells had been ringing,
All of Scotland was singing,
The old year had died,
And the new had been born.
As the news of disaster
From Ibrox came spreading,
The news that would cause
A whole nation to mourn

Two great goals had been scored,
In the last dying moments.
Jimmy Johnson for Celtic,
For Rangers’ young Stein.
Their supporters all cheered them,
With voices of thunder,
Unknowing what waited on staircase 13

66 people died
Some in flower of their manhood,
When the fences gave way
And the barriers bent,
Seasoned Glasgow policemen their faces all tearstained,
With brave efforts, endeavoured far worse to prevent.
All of Glasgow enjoined,
For the first time in history.
In the Glasgow cathedral no Billy’s, no Dan’s
But the Old Firm united to pray for their victims,
Of a tragedy set in the memory of man.

New Year Bells had been ringing,
All of Scotland was singing,
The old year had died,
And the new had been born.
As the news of disaster
From Ibrox came spreading,
The news that would cause
A whole nation to mourn.



</question>

<answer>



I wasnt born actually when it happened, but it sounds dreadful. I am so sorry for those who had relatives pass away  that day in tragic events. I agree it would have united the old firm and the divisions were all broken and crossed in an effort to do 1st aid and help those little children who lost a father that day etc.

<answer>



Yeah ok dude. Kaka gets hit by dirty defenders left and right in Italy. Gilardino has scored better goals for Milan than the two headers today. He was hardly marked and the crosses to him had to be perfect. If he can't get one of those on target he shouldn't be on Fiorentina. He'll never be as good and have the vision like Filippo Inzaghi. People like Inzaghi kept scoring at Milan despite age, idk why Gila didnt, except by Gila's own words, he just didnt feel special enough in Milan as he was not regarded as in Parma and Fiorentina as the one world class player there.

<answer from>



KENAN
Member since: 28 August 2008
Total points: 840 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Synopsis – After finishing only four points behind champions Manchester United last season and with the youngest team in the league there would appear to be a good case to be made for Arsenal taking that extra couple of steps up the table.



Particularly when you consider that they finished with eleven draws and only took six points from a possible 18 available against Liverpool, Manchester United and Chelsea.



A few draws become wins, or losses to United and Chelsea become draws or wins and the complexion of the top three changes very quickly. However, although Arsenal played some great football last season the gap between Arsenal and the top two was not accurately reflected by the final points differential.



Arsenal only conceded 31 goals last season (an improvement of four on the previous) but nowadays that is too many for a side with title aspirations. Last season United conceded 22, the year before 27, Chelsea’s championship seasons were 22 and 15, and Arsenal unbeaten season was 26.



When the chips were down the Arsenal defense was found wanting and with no changes it is doubtful that we will see an improvement in their league position this season.



In attack the drop off in goals from Adebayor (24) to the next highest highest Fabregas (8) was too great and such an over reliance on one player for goals means leans times when a dip in form hits. Nonetheless Adebayor is a solid bet for at least 15-20 Premiership goals again this season but Arsenal also needs a full season out of Van Persie, and more goals from the wide midfield positions.



They also need solid defensive cover in the centre of midfield. If Wenger can find the right player to team with Fabregas it might pay off not only in goals scored but in the goals against column as well. 
SHORT ANSWER IS NOOOOOOO!!!!!!!!!!!!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



General_...
Member since: 12 September 2008
Total points: 110 (Level 1)



</answer from>

New Year Bells had been ringing,

Jimmy Johnson for Celtic,
For Rangers’ young Stein.
Their supporters all cheered them,
With voices of thunder,
Unknowing what waited on staircase 13

Some in flower of their manhood,
When the fences gave way
And the barriers bent,
Seasoned Glasgow policemen their faces all tearstained,

For the first time in history.

<question>



Does his explain MJ's Italian obsession?



RACIAL INTOLERANCE AND "HATE SPEECH" - 
INTERNATIONAL AND CROATIAN STANDARDS AND PRACTICE

A report prepared for the round table talks of experts entitled 
«How to combat 'hate speech' and violence motivated by race»



24 March 2004-10-11
(Prepared by: Tena Erceg, Human Rights Centre, Zagreb, 2004.

"HATE SPEECH” IN CROATIA



“Hate speech” is present at all levels of the Croatian society. At the political level, state officials and government representatives tend to use insulting words and negative stereotypes when they speak about the members of national and sexual minorities and women. In the sphere of entertainment and show business, there is an extreme nationalistic trend personified as Marko Perković Thompson. In the private, individual sphere, “hate speech” has been publicly used and approved for years at higher levels of  society without any sanctions and has resulted in racist prejudice with the “common” people, particularly those of a younger age.

Taken from: http://www.human-rights.hr/dokumenti/rac...



</question>

<question>

<category>



Sports

<question from>



Trapper
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What can be done to level the EPL playing field?



Aston Villa said this week that they will struggle to pay Gareth Barry's wage demands unless they can break into the CL places this season.



The 'big' clubs are the only clubs who can afford the top quality players because they qualify for the CL regularly and they only do that because they can afford the top quality players.



So what can be done to introduce a bit of competition back into the EPL rather than have Manchester United, Chelsea, Arsenal and Liverpool playing their own league and everyone else playing theirs? Home grown player quotas? Collective salary capping? More stringent rules on clubs being bought against debt?



</question>

<question>



Scotland v Argentina?



the last time we heard of this proposal Gordon Smith was having to pay out £1million to the Argentines, and  to pay it he was going to raise the ticket prices, fans went ape, the idea was scrapped



now the game is back on at Hampden, but without the added £1million and the ticket prices are not rising, however..



am i alone in thinking Gordon Smith and the FA actually ARE shelling out this high fee to have Argentina here, and not letting on?



also, what implications is this going to have on our domestic game as money is already tight?



</question>



<answer from>



Bluebell
Member since: 10 March 2008
Total points: 13843 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Scottish Football (Soccer)



</answer from>



<answer>



they probably are..i don't see the argies coming for nothing...the sfa will just take out of the pot to suit themselves anyway..and to top it all messi aint even playing



</answer>



<answer from>



Trapper
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 119 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is a friendly, right? So what's the point?



Argentina will send their B team over, Scotland will be hit by players withdrawing from the squad. I can't see much interest in it really.



If they're secretly diverting excessive funds from the SFA for this match, I'd be appalled. Friendlies can be good for blooding new players or trying out tactics, and do cost money to organise, but shouldn't be at the expense of the proper games.



</answer>



<answer from>



Anne Marie
Member since: 28 April 2008
Total points: 5868 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



They said they had negotiated a new few but I agree with you that it doesn't all add up. Also quoted as saying that ticket prices would be up to £35 which is still high in my opinion for a bounce match.



If it is true then it will have an affect on the domestic game as money is tight as it is. Also seen a report the other day about some youth football and women's youth football having to be funded from the proceeds of crime act. Something wrong there.



</answer>

<answer>

<original file>4315.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk53009.txt</current file name>




<category>



Sports



Football (Soccer)



</category>



<question from>



Trapper
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 121 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What can be done to level the EPL playing field?



Aston Villa said this week that they will struggle to pay Gareth Barry's wage demands unless they can break into the CL places this season.



The 'big' clubs are the only clubs who can afford the top quality players because they qualify for the CL regularly and they only do that because they can afford the top quality players.



So what can be done to introduce a bit of competition back into the EPL rather than have Manchester United, Chelsea, Arsenal and Liverpool playing their own league and everyone else playing theirs? Home grown player quotas? Collective salary capping? More stringent rules on clubs being bought against debt?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



A salary cap. A club being what the name implies - a CLUB. No purchase against debt. Local player quotas - and by local I don't just mean England, think Sunderland for Sunderland, Fulham for Fulham and so on.



Maybe bite the bullet and follow Rugby - a ten minute sin bin instead of a yellow to get rid of overpriced foreign divers.



Also maybe just like the worlds banks the EPL economy is falsely inflated. Look at the money being thrown around. The clubs have became toys for rich boys and have some pretty astounding debts to banks and creditors. The banks go broke and want their money back to pay their creditors, where does that leave the clubs? Flat on their collective ar*es. Think the millionaire players will have a whip around and say to Liverpool "...never mind the yanks we've had a whip around at the pub and here's some dosh to keep the club going and never mind our salaries for the next year!" Newcastle could at least get Barton to go out and mug someone for some dosh!



</answer>

<question>



I saw a comedy sketch last night in which an Englishman was making fun at us folks from the USA ...?



...calling your football 'soccer'.I thought it was really funny...but it got me to wondering...do you all REALLY hate the fact that we use the word 'soccer'?!
lol



</question>



<additional details>



Hi Dame Carolyn...oh yes...many words!
Such as --
UK chips = US fries
UK biscuits = US cookies
UK petrol = US gas
UK bonnet = US hood (of a car)
UK tap = US faucet
and on and on...



Hello Han--OH YES!!That one too--'fanny'--lol!

<answer from>

<answer>



No, not 'hate' - that's too strong by several orders of magnitude. I suppose it's like us talking about the sport that you call football and we call American football - how does that go down in America? It's just usage of an unfamiliar term for something that's spoken about as a matter of course.



Having said which, the word 'soccer' is a contraction of 'association', which is what football/soccer was known as to distinguish it from rugby...



Mark Twain had it right I think - he described England and America as two countries divided by a common language.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Soccer is just to differentiate it from "local" football sports, like Australian Football or American Football (which is why it's called soccer in these countries as soccer is less popular than the local football). In Britain, football is THE sport. Therefore, soccer has no place in the British dictionary.



But, strictly speaking, it should be called Football since you're playing with your feett.
Australian Football, you play it with your feet as well all the time.
American Football, not so much.. but I heard that it was because, long long time ago, sports were played by riding a horse, and then when American Football was invented, it was played on foot instead of on horse.



My opinion, yes, I do hate the word Soccer. I think other "footballs" should make a new word for themselves instead of changing the name of the most popular sports in the world to become "soccer"



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>

</answer>

<answer from>



bine_ye
Member since: 03 July 2008
Total points: 185 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Consider this. Wouldn't you like to see a United Kingdom league? With transport links so much better these days, I can't see why a UK league is not possible to run. It would give the LoW and IFA teams the chance to have a higher income through sponsorship and television rights.  The divisions should be divided up so the majority of the top division in the first season are English, due to their higher quality, and place the Welsh, Scottish and Northern Irish teams in the lower divisions. The top 3 or 4 divisions should be mixed, then any lower divided in sections, as the lower teams may not be able to afford to travel all the time. These sections would be titled Division 4-England, Division 4-Scotland and so forth. Also, in the places for Europe, the Champions League and UEFA Cup places in the current "smaller" leagues (Wales, NI) should be played for in a 8-team mini tournament involving the teams of their country only or something like that.
Now the international teams, they would remain separate, as players are from their own country, simple as that, however, a United Kingdom team would be good for the Olympic Games.



I don't know if that answered your question, but I'm actually going to list this as a question of my own!



</answer>

Google have released a version of one of their first ever search engines.

<answer from>



bine_ye
Member since: 03 July 2008
Total points: 185 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Consider this. Wouldn't you like to see a United Kingdom league? With transport links so much better these days, I can't see why a UK league is not possible to run. It would give the LoW and IFA teams the chance to have a higher income through sponsorship and television rights.  The divisions should be divided up so the majority of the top division in the first season are English, due to their higher quality, and place the Welsh, Scottish and Northern Irish teams in the lower divisions. The top 3 or 4 divisions should be mixed, then any lower divided in sections, as the lower teams may not be able to afford to travel all the time. These sections would be titled Division 4-England, Division 4-Scotland and so forth. Also, in the places for Europe, the Champions League and UEFA Cup places in the current "smaller" leagues (Wales, NI) should be played for in a 8-team mini tournament involving the teams of their country only or something like that.
Now the international teams, they would remain separate, as players are from their own country, simple as that, however, a United Kingdom team would be good for the Olympic Games.



I don't know if that answered your question, but I'm actually going to list this as a question of my own!



</answer>
