<question from>



bine_ye
Member since: 03 July 2008
Total points: 185 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Would you like to see a combined United Kingdom football league?



Consider this. Wouldn't you like to see a United Kingdom league? With transport links so much better these days, I can't see why a UK league is not possible to run. It would give the LoW and IFA teams the chance to have a higher income through sponsorship and television rights.



The divisions should be divided up so the majority of the top division in the first season are English, due to their higher quality, and place the Welsh, Scottish and Northern Irish teams in the lower divisions. The top 3 or 4 divisions should be mixed, then any lower divided in sections, as the lower teams may not be able to afford to travel all the time. These sections would be titled Division 4-England, Division 4-Scotland and so forth.



Also, in the places for Europe, the Champions League and UEFA Cup places in the current "smaller" leagues (Wales, NI) should be played for in a 8-team mini tournament involving the teams of their country only or something like that.



Now the international teams, they would remain separate, as players are from their own country, simple as that, however, a United Kingdom team would be good for the Olympic Games.



</question>



<answer from>



Thomas H
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 407 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

Member since: 26 April 2006
Total points: 4329 (Level 4)

FIFA would not allow a United Kingdom team enter the Olympics and individual nations in the world cup !



Transport has improved, but Yeovil v Inverness Cally Thistle would still be an awful journey. I for one, would hate this idea - as I live in the south, but support Scunthorpe - as some teams have complained about the distances they have to travel.



A UK league would be fine for the teams, but would be rubbish for the fans.  Secondly Welsh teams are allowed in the English league already.

<question>



Do you think the strictness of the work permit regulations has a negative affect on Scottish Football?



or would you prefer your team to bring through youth players? I watched some of the Motherwell game and the Everton game last night and both British teams were outplayed by AS Nancy and Standard Liege respectively. Both of these teams were full of players from Congo, Senegal and Cameroon which are countries were the level of player is good and value for money. Do you think the regulations should be weakened to help our clubs be more competivite in Europe or do you think things are ok as they just now?



</question>



<additional details>



CC, I understood you and I agree with you to an extent. Think it comes down to are you happy with your club being oh so unlucky in Europe or actually being competitive but as you rightly say this will then have a detriment to the national side. Tough balance to keep.



I know hairy!! Thought I would try and raise the standard a bit but just for you 4IAR!!

<answer from>



Xx_cc_xX
Member since: 28 April 2008
Total points: 3095 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Scottish Football (Soccer)



</answer from>



<answer>



Where are (the once formidable) Belgium on the World Footballing map these days?



France has always had an easy 'route' into Europe for African footballers but with a population of 70million is never going to suffer in the same way we (5mil) Belgium (10mil) or even England are/will, should our homegrown talent struggle to break through thanks to cheap foreign imports.



Your options ...."Do you think the regulations should be weakened to help our clubs be more competivite in Europe or do you think things are ok as they just now?".... don't include the opinion that there are too many foreign players, which I believe to be the case (certainly in England if not here 'yet')



Obviously, making it easier for foreigners to play in our league would make the football better but would be detrimental in the long term for our game as a whole.



F***, I'm confusing myself now, hope you can understand roughly what I am on about!?



</answer>

<original file>8473.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk57628.txt</current file name>




<category>



Sports



Football (Soccer)



</category>



<question from>



Blue B
Member since: 29 June 2008
Total points: 844 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Can someone explain how betting odds work?



For instance what does the following mean.



4/9 Chelsea win



3/1 Draw



13/2 Aston Villa win



</question>



<additional details>



no, all you did was add the 2 numbers.



it would make more sense if you used the same number.



For instance: 10



</additional details>



<answer from>



Thomas H
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 409 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Put £9 on Chelsea you get £13 back.Put £1 on the draw you get £4 back. £2 on Villa you get £15 back.That ok.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bloosboy
Member since: 26 December 2007
Total points: 2589 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The first number is what you win and the second number is how much you have to stake, or gamble to win it.



So 4/9 Chelsea means you must risk 9 to win 4, or 18 to win 8, or 2.25 to win 1 etc.



3/1 Draw means that for each pound you bet you will win 3 if it is a draw. The thing to remember is that you get your stake back too, so in this example if you bet 5 pounds on the draw and it is a draw you get back 5 x 3 = 15 plus your 5 stake = 20 total and a profit of 15.



</answer>

<answer>



graceful, elegant, clinical, FRAGILE



He is a great player, and the one and only reason he isn't regarded as he deserves to be is because he has been consistently getting injured and his service has only been ever available for 1/4 of the season. This season, all Arsenal fans will admit he has been lasting pretty long so far, 5 out of 6 games may be a new record for him. But we all bite our fingernails when watching him play because we fear he may get injured at some point. Which he did in that game he could have well gotten his first hat trick for the club. Instead he had to come off and Adebayor got the hat trick. He could have also gotten one against Porto, but injury awareness led Wenger to take him off early and Adebayor took the penalty he would have taken instead.
If van Persie played a full season, he would be competing for premier league golden boot, possibly even UEFA. His goals/game record is unmatched. But he only gets 15-20 goals per season because he only plays 15-20 games per season or maybe less.



Both are good jersey choices. van Persie is already established as a great player and Theo is still in the process of making his name.



</answer>

<question>



Do you love it or hate it?



A little man who loved the circus was delighted when it came to town for 2 weeks.He booked front row tickets for every performance.On the first night it started with the clowns and everyone was laughing at the little clown.The clown went up to the little man and pointed and shouted,what are you laughing at me for look at this guy his eyes are like dinner plates.The wee man was so embarrassed he got up and went home.On the second night the same thing happened what are you doing laughing at me,he's got eyes like LP's.So the wee guy left and was very upset and told his pal he couldn't go back.His pal said wait a minute have you heard of Simon Dupree' , the wee man says no.So he hands him a card and says he'll sort it for you.The wee man reads the card Simon Dupree' the master of sarcasm and wit,Anyone giving you trouble give me a call and i'll sort it,my sarcasm and wit is an art to me that i've practised for many years,and I can use it in any given situation to tear anyone to pieces,So he called the number and Mr Dupree's secretary made an appointment for the next day because he had a space due to cancellation.So the wee man goes to his home and it's a big mansion he has to speak through an intercom to get through the gate,He had to walk through acres of grounds to get to the house.Outside the house was a fleet of cars. Limo's Rolls,Royces Bentleys etc.He rang the bell and the butler answered.The wee man states his business and is shown to Mr Dupree's study.
He walks in the door and is dazzled by this man,he is six feet four with a boxers build,his clothes are immaculate.it is the most impressive sight the wee man has ever seen.The wee man tells his story.Simon Dupree' says yes,I take great pleasure in jobs like this,that clown sounds like a nasty piece of work.He said my fee is one thousand pounds.The wee man said i've only got 300 it's my life savings.Mr Dupree' says Hmmm I really want this one, so i'll do a deal with you,wash all my cars and i'll do it for 300.So the wee man washes all the cars he knocks his pan in for 8 hours.Then Mr Dupree' says, get into my Bentley,we're going to the circus.They get to the circus the clowns come on the wee man is laughing along with everyone else,the clown goes to the wee man,points and says look at this joker if you want a laugh his eyes are like dustbin lids.The wee man smiles and looks at Mr Dupree'.He stands up the arena is silent.He says to the clown allow me to introduce myself my name is Simon Dupree'  this man beside me is a dear friend of mine and if you don't stop slagging him i'll punch your head in.



</question>

<answer>

It works in other sports - it would work in soccer.
It's ludicrous that, under certain conditions, one dubious decision by a referee, can affect a club to the tune of many millions of pounds.



</answer>



<answer from>



scubview
Member since: 11 June 2007
Total points: 332 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>

<answer from>



Robbie
Member since: 07 March 2008
Total points: 678 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi



Just like in any other profession, if not already, all referees should be addressed by a senior person/official and de-brief the decisions they have made on their games (good or bad) on a weekly or monthly basis.  They should be praised where they have refereed well such as high profile matches where the players can be a bit of a handful and also highlight and address any exceptional levels of bad decision/refereeing.  In the case of the latter, a plan could be set with realistic goals to ensure that the error levels drop within  a specific time period and if this doesn't happen then the referee would be issued with a formal warning upon the next meeting.  If matters still didn't improve then the referee would be made redundant.  I really don't see why this management style which is used in so many occupations can't be applied to Sport.



Source(s):



Common sense management.



</answer>

<question from>



gogomila...
Member since: 31 January 2008
Total points: 1710 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Who will be in AC Milan's group in the UEFA Cup?



</question>



<answer from>



liverpool 2 man utd 1
Member since: 17 March 2007
Total points: 4174 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The draw for the group stage of the 2008–09 UEFA Cup will be held at UEFA Headquarters in Nyon, Switzerland, at 12:00CET on 7 October 2008. The 40 teams in the draw will be divided into five pots based on their UEFA coefficients. The eight teams with the highest UEFA coefficient will be allocated to Pot 1, the next eight teams to Pot 2, and so on. One team from each pot will be drawn for each group, with the restriction that no team may be drawn with one from the same country.



ac milan are in pot 1.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for the information.



</asker's comment>

<question from>



El Problema
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 2226 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Liverpool fans, was yesterdays game another sign of how much better we are this season?



Last night we played half a team of players who would usually be either on the bench or not involved at all...Hyypia, Pennant, Lucas and Babel obviously aren't first team players. Skrtel, Agger, Mascherano and Torres didn't play. Riera and Keane didn't start. This is the sort of fixture we would have drawn last season, and right now we would probably be grumbling about Rafa and his rotation. But this season we're coming back from European fixtures & big league games and still winning. Last season every time we played in the CL you just knew we would play poorly in the next league game and usually draw. The result against Stoke is the exception, but the game itself was completely one sided and should have ended 3 or 4 - nil. This to me shows real DEPTH in the squad.



See where I'm coming from?



</question>



<additional details>



Duke Lucas: That's exactly my point. We scrapped and went on to win a game we would have drawn last season. But we won. And by the way, didn't you also say you really believed Spurs would finish 3rd this season? Ha ha, how's that working out for ya? ;-)



Stu: Yup, that's what I'm getting at...Lucas is shite compared to most of our players but we still dominated the game!



</additional details>

Attacking Aspect for Chelsea.



Drogba very good in shooting. Drogba Scores.
Ballack crosses very well. Lampard scores.



Defence.



Bosnigwa, Cole very weak players in running but John Terry very good.



But Cech very Good.



Lots of goal scares from Sunderland.



Sunderland Attack.



Kieren Richardson to attack far from the left and attack and cause the major scarces.

<question>



Whats your views on this ?



Do you Gers fans believe you are being Victimised or has the power of Paranoia caught up with you lot ?
http://www.randalstowncsc.net/home/modul...



</question>



<answer from>



Anne Marie
Member since: 28 April 2008
Total points: 6616 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Scottish Football (Soccer)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Victimised? God that's hilarious. There is a large section of the gers support who deliberately want to push the boundaries and chuck their dummies out of the pram if they are not allowed to say what they want. John Reid was correct  when he said this is a vile vicious and racist song which has no place in Scottish Football. Action should have been taken when it was first sang last season. Now due to the lack of action from the SFA, SPL, Rangers and the police until hopefully now, you will maybe get one or 2 token arrests to just to prove they are doing something then creating a powderkeg at most games. I felt really sorry for the racist guy who posted on Follow Follow, saying how he won't be back as he cant sing the racist song or the billy boys anymore. He said that Minty is to blame for ruining what is his "kulture" when following The Rangers. It's 2008 for crying out loud, why dont they do something novel and make up a couple of new songs about their own club instead of deflecting away from the issue.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Interesting reply Anne Marie, I have often said recently that Rangers fans should be looking to put some new songs instead of harping on about the 'Billy Boys' getting binned. I still get embarrassed when our fans sing the likes of 'Boys of the old Brigade' etc at away games. 2008 time 2 move on. x



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Erra Polis!
Member since: 28 April 2006
Total points: 591 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i think the whole thing has been blown so big compared to similar - if not more offensive - happenings at other games.  why are Rangers being victimised?



Why are we the only club to be getting this stick?



every celtic away game this season has had sectarian singing.  the aberdeen fans still sing about ibrox disasters.  hearts have their songs too.  im not point scoring against celtic here but common sense must prevail - the SFA, the SPL, Celtic, the Daily Record, The Sun, the rest of Murdoch's media empire, Irish Government, heads of the Catholic church... what does it have to do with the last two?  Nothing.  Ireland can stay out of Scotland, and the religious people (any religious people) should stay out of football - or the problem WONT go away.



yet not one thing about other songs (and no punishment or investigation whatsoever).  When Celtic sang in Inverness, there was a column about an inch wide in the Sun.  When Rangers sing the famine song...  theres a ten page pull out.



so why just the famine song?



Source(s):



http://www.stv.tv/news/Police_are_victim...



</answer>

<question from>



Mr Lover is a Gunner!
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 1262 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



If i pay for my ticket can i have an opinion?



Since David Seaman us Arsenal fans have not been in full confidence of our goalkeepers, now i admit that isn't helping them but i remember once i sat behind the goal and shouted support for Jens Lehmann and he had a good game now i felt that i maybe have helped him a little. When Lehmann made mistakes he paid for it yet we still loved him and i thank him for everything he did for the club.



Now Almunia when he changed his hair colour he didn't fool anyone he was still the same keeper, he makes good saves but he also makes a lot of mistakes and i bet Gallas and Toure would like a solid keeper behind them which would make their lives easier. All keepers make mistakes but when keepers like Cech make mistakes i bet John Terry knows its a one off but with Almunia he will let it effect him. I will not abuse Almunia and i will shout support while hes an Arsenal keeper but surely Wenger has to realise that we cannot win the league with someone like him in goal.



So to complain i come on places like these to voice my opinions.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Since Cech's won Golden Glove Award and KOTY (Keeper Of The Year)



3 times...when he makes a mistake...he makes about 3 a season ;)



I think Wenger has to realise than Almunia is still young for a Goalkeeper , and Lehmann should still be at Arsenal..Almunia wasn't his understudy as he was always ahead of Lehmann for a time



Wenger needs to buy a keeper who's ATLEAST 30 as they are always in there prime round about that age , except the very exceptional ones , even if he bought Dida from A.C Milan..he would bring so much experience to Arsenal...he would keep the back 4 in check...and Almunia would learn a lifes worth with him..or anyone like that



</answer>

<question>



When was the last time Arsenal conceded 4 goals at home?



</question>



<additional details>



Very good GER C!



I did of course mean before last night.



</additional details>



<answer from>



hari k
Member since: 18 October 2008
Total points: 139 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



In EPL, the last time Arsenal conceded 4 goals at home was against Man Utd on 1 Feb 2005.



The Score was 2-4.



Giggs, Ronaldo(2) and O'Shea scored for ManUtd.



Viera and Bergkamp was the scorers for Arsenal



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Very comprehensive answer, cheers.



</asker's comment>

<category>



Sports

<question from>



H
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What are the 3 stages of warming up in football and netball?



All I want to know is what the 3 stages of warming up are called for football and netball



</question>



<answer from>



CFC[IS]B...
Member since: 20 May 2007
Total points: 5237 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Generaly i just thought it was "Warm Up" as one?
then a Cool Down..



Running
Stretching
Jog



</answer>



<answer from>



A Person
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 2260 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



There's four.



1. Cardiovascular (Jogging etc.)
2. Static stretching (Hamstrings, Quadricepts etc.)
3. Dynamic Stretching(Stetching while on the move)
4. Activity related (Use of a football/netball)



</answer>

<answer>



Hi Sammy.



Technically there is no such thing as Free-to-air TV in the UK as there is the TV licence and even for basic sattelite tv/cable TV packages there is a subscription fee before adding any Sports channels.



Therefore, as idealistic as it may sound I personally think all sport should be free to all formats of TV as it will help get more people into sport and hopefully living healthier lifestyles.



The broadcasters will still make their money through the advertisers who want their product to be seen in the breaks between coverage of the big teams and clubs will arguably make more money as more people will then be able to watch the games and therefore be more likely to "buy in" to a certain club and spend their money on that club's kits and merchandise.



Best wishes to you and all at Barca.



Rob (Barca fan)



</answer>

<answer from>



Captain Starkiller
Member since: 10 April 2007
Total points: 25038 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Politics



</answer from>



<answer>



All national matches should be on free-to-air channels is my personal view.  I like the system in the UK where the BBC has access to highlights on Match of the Day, while subscription channels squabble over live matches.  The only problem is that international matches are on subscription channels as well.
But really, the choice should be up to the various football associations.  If they want people to follow football, they should ensure that certain games are free.  I do not see many people paying to watch matches with the current credit crunch, especially if it means having to subscribe to different TV channels.



Cricket made a mistake in the UK when they sold out to Sky, especially as being on free-to-air television enabled loads of people to watch the Ashes winning series, and increased the popularity of Cricket.  Since the swtich to channel five with its limited coverage, the number of the general population following the game has dropped, and that will mean less people being interested in it in the future, which means less players and less fans.



Both clubs and the national assoication in the UK needs to bear that in mind, especially with the way the finances dropped out in Serie A, as this can happen in the UK.  Too many clubs in the Premier League play to grounds that are not full to capacity, even when they are playing the big teams.  When the premier league is ridden with debt, decreasing coverage will mean less interest in the game.  And that will be bad for clubs saddled with debt as well as the interests of the national game.



Source(s):



http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2008/...



</answer>



<answer from>



truth seeker
Member since: 21 May 2008
Total points: 403 (Level 2)

I think the games should be split between Terrestrial TV and the sky sports channels.  This is only fair and this is what we paid for.  At the moment we are all watching live streaming of the games - why the hell would we want to pay again - its not fair.

<question>



What's the deal with Juventus?



I caught a glimpse of them last Saturday, when they allowed a late goal to lose to Napoli.  This proud old program is currently 12th in Serie A.  Yet at the moment, they're beating Real Madrid... Perhaps I spoke too soon, RVN just scored to make it 2-1 Juve.  But to hear some tell it, RM is "the best team in the world." How can Juventus be struggling so in their league and leading such a team in the Champions League?



</question>

2-1 to Juve, a final.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Bloosboy
Member since: 26 December 2007
Total points: 3037 (Level 4)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>

</answer>

<question>



Does Leo Messi have any flaws?



Everytime I see him play he is nothing short of amazing with the ball glued to his boot but since I don't see him play every week - does he have a week part to his game that I haven't seen yet?



</question>



<answer from>



Will Slug For Food *
Member since: 02 June 2007
Total points: 9031 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



His right foot isn't too strong.  He is brilliant and goes balls out for every ball that comes near him.  He puts forth more effort than any player on the pitch and is typical for Argentine forwards - esp. Tevez.  He does tend to over exert himself and be drained by about the 75th minute - with good reason.



</answer>



<answer from>



Aztec Soldier
Member since: 24 March 2008
Total points: 6972 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



He is great at dribbling, jukes, shooting passing, freekicks but i think he needs to work on his defense (meaning taking away the ball from others)

<answer from>



Ian L
Member since: 05 December 2007
Total points: 478 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Messi is an excellent player for sure.  As far as flaws go, the most prominent one is his reluctance to use his right foot.  Fortunately, his outrageously quick cuts and ball retention skills overshadow this flaw.  I've also seen him get frustrated whilst losing.  This frustration tends to manifest in the form of selfishness. While trailing, I've seen him repeatedly look to force the ball through himself.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 03 July 2008

<question from>



KOL-LFC
Member since: 10 June 2007
Total points: 1178 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



What Makes The Perfect Goal (soccer) ?



Curl, Dip, Distance, Run etc
What is the perfect combination for the perfect goal ?



</question>



<answer from>



tooniron
Member since: 26 April 2006
Total points: 4902 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The perfect goal requires a lot of factors



i) Timing in the game : a winning goal in the last minute will always be better than the same goal scored in a 5-0 demolition.



ii) Who scores it : we all have our own particular teams/players and their goals will always be better



iii) Who did you score past : again we have teams we dislike, and to see them concede is always better



iv) Importance : Scoring in a final, at wembley beats a 1st round Johnstone's Paint Trophy away game at Halifax



Then you get into the technicality of the goal, and for me it would involve beating a couple of players (not just running quicker than them, but actually using skill to get past), shot from outside the box, and wide from the goal, curling (rather than sheer power) past the keeper into the top corner, preferably going in off the post/crossbar.



Having said that, for me the perfect goal was just a simple header scored by Alex Calvo-Garcia in the play-off final at wembley (1-0 final score) against Leyton Orient (who I don't dislike) for Scunthorpe United (my team).



Whereas technically I'd go for Jermaine Beckford's goal for Scunthorpe v Rotherham two seasons ago.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Great, but a long distance curling free-kick was always be my favourite.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Alicia
Member since: 28 October 2006
Total points: 4722 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



a nice one two pass at the flanks...a run pass the defender sending a perfect cross in with the striker running in the box finding himself an open space doin a bicycle kick on the ball and into the net...



or



the keeper comes out for a corner kick and scores with a header in injury time to win a cup or championship...



</answer>



<answer from>



marchgoo...
Member since: 07 April 2006
Total points: 268 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



the perfect goal is one that when it hits the back of the net the place goes nuts but a 25-35 dead straight shot is worth it's weight in gold.



Source(s):



25 years of playing pro soccer



</answer>

Member since: 18 October 2008

<answer>



Jose Mourinho ..... well, well, well ..... long time no see! Before i answer YOUR question, could i please ask you 2 myself?



1. Do you want to come back to the EPL one day ?
2. Will you marry me ? ;-P



Your question ... it shouldnt affect a refs decision in the slightest, they (supposedly) know the rules and should therefore ignore whatever the fans may be saying/shouting ... the refs decision is final, and if it is found that a decision was made by a ref because of fan pressure then he should be kicked out of the job, because that isnt being neutral is it!



Now back to my proposal ...................??



</answer>



<answer from>



rainfall...
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 1166 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think it often has the adverse effect. Referees are mindful of the perceived bias towards the home team and react too strongly often waving away legitimate penalty calls because they are put off by the noise from the crowd. Then again sometimes slight or petty offences like moving forward a few yards to take a throw in are brought to the referee's attention by the crowd. In these instances the "pressure" from the crowd may be the only matter that alerts the referee to cheating. So its a mixed bag.



</answer>



<answer from>



Are you going with me
Member since: 07 April 2008
Total points: 4553 (Level 4)

<answer>

They WILL change their mind if their Linesman points out something NOT the players.



</answer>

<answer>



Dear Mr Mourinho,
Here and there and for ages soccer fans have said a lot about refereeing decisions affected by pressure from ... fans of the competing team. It may be true - as for cases revealed, and may not be true - as for cases undetected. Things getting worse as referees are kings with absolute rights; hence, it is just a waste of time to meditate on whether such affecting exists or how it makes refereeing decisions distorted. There is only one way to overwhelm all these eternal headaches: to score as many as possible the net of the opponent's side. You train your players in whatever best way you can to make them make score of say over ten for every match, and let those referees do their job as they can never whistle a NO to all the ten scores of your team within a match. This is both positive and proactive, I dare say.
Regards,
Hoang Huu Phuoc from Vietnam



</answer>

<answer from>



probably...
Member since: 05 June 2007
Total points: 10792 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Psychological studies have proved many times that group pressure works. Many studies show that a single person tested in a group of "stooges" will begin to agree with the group even when they know that they are saying something wrong.



Refs are professionals but they are human beings and their decisions will be affected by tens of thousands of people screaming for blood. It's human nature.



Most refs do a great job. We watch TV or see the screen at a match and see an incident over and over and think we are experts because we see something after the third replay.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 08 April 2006
Total points: 173 (Level 1)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Maria,Beckham's best position is either on the right wing or at right-back,where he can provide the best pin-point crosses.We all know what would happen if Beckham is played in midfield.As for your question,Marco,Seedorf, Ronaldinho,Pato,Shevchenko,Inzaghi,Luiz Ronaldo and Borriello better beware.The moment Beckham goes to Milan,he'll automatically seal his place in the right wing and combine with Zambrotta on the right flank,with Kaka and Jankulovski on the left.Hence it's up to Seedorf and Ronaldinho to wrestle for a place on either the left wing or support striker and Pato,Ronaldo,Shevchenko, Inzaghi and Borriello to wrestle for a spot at chief striker.Pato could also play as support striker if Milan decide to pair Pato with an out-and-out striker.There's also a possibility of Ronaldinho and Kaka playing together up front if Ancelotti decides to play both Beckham and Seedorf on the flanks,or play Pirlo in midfield,Kaka,Ronaldinho,Pato and Ronaldo,Shevchenko,Inzaghi or Borriello as strikers with Beckham at right-back.If Ancelotti decides not to play Pirlo or Seedorf,Ronaldinho can partner Gattuso in midfield,with Beckham and Kaka on the flanks and Pato partnering Ronaldo,Shevchenko,Inzaghi or Borriello up front.If Ancelotti decides not to play Ronaldinho either,Kaka can also move to central midfield,with Pato on the left wing and Shevchenko,Ronaldo,Inzaghi or Borriello wrestling for a place up front.Overall if Beckham arrives to Milan,Ancelotti has many options on how to play Beckham,Kaka,Ronaldinho,Pirlo,Pato,Ronal... Shevchenko,Inzaghi,Borriello,Gattuso,Zam... and Seedorf.But Ancelotti should remember what happened to Real Madrid during the Galacticos era when Beckham and Owen arrived at Real Madrid and what happened to Barcelona last season when Thierry Henry arrived and Krcic and dos Santos started to blossom at Barcelona.Even now Pep Guardiola is still facing a dilemma on how to play Henry,Krcic, Eto'o,Hleb,Keita,Iniesta,Gudjohnsen and Pedrito alongside Messi in Barcelona's 4-3-3 formation.Similarly Ancelotti is still facing a dilemma on how to play Flamini,Gattuso,Pirlo,Ambrosini,Kaka,Ron... Shevchenko,Pato,Ronaldo,Inzaghi or Borriello in the same team in Milan's 4-4-2 formation.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Do your kids support the same football team as you?



The children of Manchester United legend David Beckham have been photographed wearing Chelsea shirts. See: http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/footbal...



Do your children support the same team as you?  Have you influenced their choice - and, if so, in what ways?!



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I vividly remember going home as a child and telling my dad that I was going to support Manchester United because my friend John did. He replied "Oh no you're not!" and handed me an Arsenal history book, telling me how he had been there when they won the double in 1971, how my granddad had been to all their matches in the 40s & 50s, and how my great-granddad was at the first ever match at Highbury.



I'm very glad he did - I feel a real attachment to Arsenal knowing my family have been supporting them for almost 100 years. I'll definitely be making sure my kids follow Arsenal too! :)



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm from Manchester so by the time I have kids, they'll probably choose either of the home teams anyway (unless united crumble without SAF).



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It's a game, it's supposed to be for enjoyment but people take it far too seriously. Why shouldn't children (or anyone else) be allowed to support whoever they choose? It doesn't matter it's only a game, a stupid one played by ridiculously overpaid idiots, but it's a game. It isn't going to influence the fate of the planet if someone doesn't support the "right" team.



For the same reason people who have no interest in football should not have to put up with having it shoved down our throats every day.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>

If he had have wanted to support another team there wouldn't be much I could do but he didn't.

<question>



Can americans be called soccer fans if they go for teams in Europe?



I mean comeon support your own mls team or if your mexican the mexican teams, it disgusts me to c all these people having man u and chelsea jerseys and calling your self a fan. And if ur american dont u think u purpose is going for USA not Brazil....... ur thoughts



</question>



<answer from>



Macca
Member since: 22 September 2008
Total points: 1117 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Other - Soccer



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think that American fans are just different in the fact that they are more like armchair supporters. The reason i say that is because in England people go to home games and away games. Thousands of people will even fly to Spain, Germany or Russia to watch their team play. Please correct me if i'm wrong but i don't hear of thousands of people flying up from L.A. to watch a game in Toronto.
I think that there is a difference between a fan and a supporter.
I do understand what you are talking about when it comes to supporting your country. It makes no sense for a person born and raised in America supporting Brazil or Italy even if their great grandfather was an Italian or a Brazilian.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



nice answer but look at the size of america compared to england. I mean here in LA we have the largest fan base but only maybe less than 20 will travel to an away but if its closer we can get maybe 300. But mls just doesnt have a large enough fan base to travel.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



empyre02
Member since: 21 February 2008
Total points: 656 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Here's my opinion.



The premise of showing support to the nearest team to where you live just because your in a certain area is a bit silly to me because people will gravitate to what they see on TV and want to see the highest level of competition. Not to mention all the non-MLS and MLS haters that ride bandwagons a bit too much. But for me I fell in love with football when i started watching Liverpool FC in 2002. From that I also began watching MLS and after some time started supporting the US MNT and Chivas USA as my MLS team.( I live in Phoenix we have no MLS team, yet).



It is hard for people to see what they are missing when ESPN will barley televise an MLS match which makes me sick. I mean for god sakes they'll show me food eating contests and world series of poker ALL DAY but not nearly enough MLS or US MNT support. It's like you have to work hard to get enough real football matches seen. Now if they showed more MLS games and dedicated some time and marketing into it, you would see more supporters coming out of the woodworks. This is why people support european teams and UEFA is all over TV.



As far as the US team is concerned? I think people like to cheer for winning teams. For some reason people are not aware (or care) how far the team has gotten in recent years. I keep telling people to watch and spread the world about it because there isn't nearly enough exposure. When people I know do watch, for the most part they enjoy and root for the US. We just need more time and exposure and if we do well in the world cup people will start to get excited, you'll see.



</answer>

and dont even be bothered about fans in the united states because it will take time for the U.S team and mls clubs to attract fans and to get better because u have, football, baseball, golf, hockey and all those sports come before soccer in this country and that will be a very hard step for soccer to overcome in this country.
so yeah...americans can definately be soccer fans if they go for teams in europe because it shows that they have a real knowledge and passion for soccer and honestly, europeans have more passion than U.s when it comes to soccer because it is their number one sport and nearly everyone else in the world ranks soccer as their number one dat is the difference...if U.S.A could apply the same passion  they have in football and basketball, the face of soccer would change in this country but it is very important that as a soccer fan, in the U.S, u must know the european clubs because i mean...come on..the best soccer is played there and u cant blame one for loving it

On this day in 1517, Martin Luther posted a proposal to debate the doctrine and practice of indulgences, popularly known as the 95 Theses. How bout these ?



1. What does THFC stand for? Tottenham Heading For the Championship.



2. A little boy gets £10 for his birthday and rushes down to the sports shop to buy the new football he has been desperate for. He gives the ball to the shopkeeper, who says, "Sorry, son, this ball is £20. You only have £10". The boy says, "OK, if you blindfold me and I can guess the name of the club on any ball, will you give it to me for £10?" He agrees and gives the boy an Arsenal ball. "I can hear cannons blasting, so it's an Arsenal ball." Next he gives him a Millwall ball: "I hear lions, so it's Millwall." Amazed, the shopkeeper says, "Get this and you can have it for nothing." The boy listens and says Spurs. The man asks if he's heard a cockerel. "No," says the boy. "It's going down."



More ?



3. When a groggy Vedran Corluka regained consciousness in the ambulance leaving the Britannia Stadium on Sunday he asked medical staff who he was. On being told he played football for Tottenham Hotspur he lapsed into a coma.



4. A man was found dead floating in the Thames, wearing a blond wig, full make-up, bra, knickers, suspenders and a Spurs shirt. Before informing the next of kin the police removed the Spurs shirt to save the family embarrassment.



Couldn't help but share



Arsenal &gt; Tottenham

My personal favourite;
A man and his dog, a little jack russell, go into a pub and sky sports is showing on a big screen. The score reads Spurs 0-1 Hull. The little dog jumps up and shouts "for gods sake!" The man behind the bar looks at the dog, obviously gobsmacked, and says, "that's amazing! your dog can talk?!" The dog-owner says "well yeah, he says that every time Spurs lose, he's a massive Spurs fan you see". The Bartender says "well what does he say when Spurs win?!" The owner says "I don't know, I've only had him 6 months!"



Ha.

<question>



How important is November going to be for Rangers?



With 7 matches and 21 points up for grabs in November how important must it be for us to pick up maximum points. Barry Ferguson will be back against ICT on Saturday but will almost certainly not play all 7 matches in a row. We have a pretty much fully fit squad now with the exceptions of Hemdani and Naismith as players like Burke, Whittaker and Mcculloch have all successfully played reserve games. Young spaniard Aaron Niguez is also up to match sharpness so will also surely figure in the next few games.



Do you not agree it is imperative that Walter gets the correct balance of players on the pitch in each and every game while he has most of his resources at his disposal and not leave ANYBODY waiting in the shadows of the first team??



Whats your views my friends??



</question>



<answer from>



Erra Polis!
Member since: 28 April 2006
Total points: 639 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Finally we will see the strongest squad in Scottish football battling to get into the first team.  Most will get their chance.  But every one of them will be raring to go.



Personally i can see a cricket score against caley this week.  Take 21 points and we will be back on top.  I also see Celtic slipping up before we take our game in hand.



Ferguson back will give the team a lift, no matter who has to make way for him.  Id like to see Aaron get a game tomorrow too, but introducing Barry to the midfield might be enough of a change to the most solid midfield in the country.



Boyd and Lafferty will be banging in goals for fun over the coming weeks.



We are the people.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 26 November 2007
Total points: 4597 (Level 4)

Celtic v Inverness Caledonian Thistle



The only potential pitfall there is the same as you lot Hearts away, so to say we'll slip up and lose points, seems more like wishful thinking than anything.

<question>



Hull, Fulham, Sunderland, Spurs?



What is it that these wee teams have over Arsenal this season?
Is it our central defence that really needs looked at?



</question>



<additional details>



Prem P - i read the first sentence of your answer then realised you can't take a joke, cos that what it is when i said wee teams.  Lol, took ages before someone bit though eh?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Prem P
Member since: 03 September 2008
Total points: 1061 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Your defense might need improving but not as much as yourself personally. I really think you hardly know what your talking about when you call them teams wee teams.



Fulham was founded in 1879 and are still going  strong today. Theyve risen up from third division to Premiership in a matter of seasons and are still going through and increasing their support base. Also they have none other than Mohammed Al Fayed as a chairman. Wee team? i dont think so?



Hull City have just come into the Premiership and have no high profile players except maybe their record £2.5 million signing Gardner. Their position considers them premiership contenders even though theyve just got up and are currently above Man City, Everton, Portsmouth and even the almight Man Utd. I dont see how anyone can call this team a wee team.



Sunderland have arguably the best manager in the Premiership there. They are not a wee team at all.Even Man Utd are thinking about getting Roy Keane as their next manager which means its likely that in his career he will win every major competition. The players hes got are very underated too. Theres a lot of players in that first team who have tasted success.



Spurs have been favourites to be the most likely team to break the top 4. I know this season they havent been brilliant but I still think tottenham are the most likely to make the top 4 the top 5. With the players and attitude they got, they are probably the most entertaining team in the Premiership.



You are female so you knowledge about football is very limited. Stick with baking cakes sweetheart.



Source(s):



haha. I must admit. u got me.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Does your club do enough for local charity in the area it surrounds?



Can you give me an example of what it does.



Cheers



</question>



<answer from>



Krissy Boyd *****
Member since: 02 August 2008
Total points: 1984 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The Rangers Charity Foundation



During its first three years the Foundation has given over £180,000 in support of nine charity projects. It has also provided over £480,000 of in kind support to hundreds of groups and individuals.



The Foundation is working with the British Heart Foundation, Guide Dogs and the National Deaf Children's Society (NDCS).



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 10 March 2008
Total points: 16529 (Level 6)

<answer>



for arsenal:



best players would have to be cesc, clichy and van persie. cesc is an amazing talent and can spread the ball all over the park and through the tiniest pin holes. amazing passes and can really open up a defense. Robin has a wicked left boot and his foot skills are amazing. he has great movement and a killer instinct infront of goal. lets just hope he continues to stay healthy. clichy is the MAN. he knows how to defend well and attack. he is constantly up and down the flank. he has great technical ability and know when and where to be. creates lots of scoring opportunities and covers well on D. just a great player.



worst. ... a lot of people ave been bagging on almunia lately but i dont tihnk he is all that bad. he has had some remarkable saves especially against the hammers. but bentley's goal definitely could have been saved. that being said, i dont think he is as bad as everyone else is making him out to be. on the other hand, a lot of people have been praising denilson. i recall a game where, no lie, everytime he touched the ball he gave it directly away to the opposing team 8 times in a row. his role is to get teh ball back from them not recieve a pass from your mate and then give it to the opposition. i know he is still young but i think he is by far the weak link in the starting XI at the moment. i definitely rate song higher but last night after the two of them completely turned off in the dyign minutes of the match, i just dotn know who i rate higher.



</answer>

<answer>



Currently, Liverpool. They have a fantastic squad and are undefeated in the past 16 games, two of which have been against rivals Manchester United and Chelsea. They are in the top of the league table (up by three, Chelsea in second), top of their Champions League group (which has challenging teams such as Atletico Madrid), and their potential is limitless.
Of all time? Liverpool. They have the most European titles and domestic titles.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 30 June 2008
Total points: 6135 (Level 5)



</answer from>

You agree to not use the Service to:



upload, post, email or otherwise transmit any Content that is unlawful, harmful, threatening, abusive, harassing, tortious, defamatory, vulgar, obscene, libellous, invasive of another's privacy, hateful, or racially, ethnically or otherwise objectionable;



Don't use Yahoo! Answers as a soapbox to vent your frustrations, rant, or otherwise violate the question and answer format. If you prefer to have discussions or chat with others, please use one of Yahoo!'s other community services, such as Yahoo! Groups or Yahoo! Messenger Chat Rooms.



Because kids as young as 13 may participate in Yahoo! Answers, sexually explicit and vulgar language and images are not welcome on the site. Also not welcome are belligerence, insults, slurs and generally objectionable speech. If you wouldn't say it in public, don't post it on Answers



Don't create multiple accounts to troll or otherwise violate these guidelines or the Yahoo! Terms of Service. Don't post things that are incomprehensible or in the wrong language, and don't post the same question over and over again. The community depends on you to report abuse and rate questions and answers, so using product features such as report abuse and ratings to target others is not allowed



Yahoo! Answers is a publicly accessible area. You should exercise caution if you choose to disclose personally identifiable information on a publicly accessible area. Remember that this information may remain indefinitely in the publicly accessible area. Also, there are various functions on Answers that allow other Answers’ users to view all your answers and questions collectively.



</answer>

<answer>



I can't help but go back to my feelings that censorship is wrong. In a free country a man should be able to sing and say what they want. For example i might personally despise fascists but i'd still grant them their view. For me, the minute we say that, ' in our perfect society we will not tolerate this or that groups opinions', for me that is the end of democracy. Don't get me wrong i'm a commie/republican (not a stalinist) if that makes any sense!, but at no time can we appreciate the ideal of freedom unless we also accept that other people will differ from us to varying degrees. I personally despise fascism, but without the fascists to gauge our differences against, how could we categorise what the left wing actually means. Yin Yang for me.

<answer>



In 1991 Red Star Belgrade played 2:2 with Bayern Munich at home.
Since Red star won 2:1 in Munich, they advanced to the final of the Champions leauge, which they later won.



What made it even more exciting is that Bayern was leading 2:1 in Belgrade, but Red star somehow managed to score the goal in the overtime. Just imagine 100,000 fotball fans going wild after this goal.



I was only two at the time, so although I do not remember it, I was at the game with my dad.



I get goosebumps when I watch that second goal even today...



</answer>

An Irish daughter had not been home for over 5 years. Upon her return, her father cursed her.



Where have ye been all this time? Why did ye not write to us, not even a line? Why didn't ye call? Can ye not understand what ye put yer old mum thru?



The girl, crying, replied, "Sniff, sniff....dad....I became a prostitute...."



"Ye what!!? Out of here, ye shameless harlot! Sinner! You're a disgrace to this family."



"OK, dad-- as ye wish. I just came back to give mum this luxurious fur coat, title deed to a ten bedroom mansion plus a savings certificate for £5 million."



"For me little brother, this gold Rolex and for ye daddy, the sparkling new Mercedes limited edition convertible that's parked outside plus a membership to the country club....(takes a breath)....and an invitation for ye all to spend New Years' Eve on board my new yacht in the Riviera, and...."



Now what was it ye said ye had become?" says dad.



Girl, crying again, "Sniff, sniff....a prostitute dad! Sniff, sniff.



"Oh! Be Jesus! Ye scared me half to death, girl! I thought ye said a protestant. Come here and give yer old man a hug!"

<question>



Looking at buying my boyfriend a really decent pair of football boots but dunno where 2 start any suggesstions?



i dunno what are the best sort im purely going off price, the more expensive the better is this true?



</question>



<answer from>



Frank L
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



All depends on the individual. Some manufactures suit wider feet some suit thinner ones etc.



I play Semi-Professional football and most of the players i play with or against opt for 'Joma' or 'Valsport' boots.



But you cant go wrong in my opinion with Adidas boots.



www.prodirectsoccer.com is a good start.



</answer>



<answer from>



GIGGS is OO7©
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 36 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



a football boot is not a fashion statement or a type of footware. Its a piece of equipment. If your boyfriend is lucky enough to have EXACTLY the same dimensions as the professional footballer that a particlar set of boots are designed brilliant. Otherwise he needs to be there to pick them himself, i borrowed a pair of boots of iain dowie for a charity match, i would have been better playing in my trainers !



</answer>
